intro: Cracca dimorphophylla, commonly known as the two-leaf cracca, is a striking member of the Rubiaceae family native to southern Africa. This plant is characterized by its distinctive leaves, which are divided into two contrasting lobes, giving it its common name. It produces small, clustered white flowers that bloom in spring, followed by bright red berries that attract various bird species. The plant thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important component of its native habitat.
